title: Ask Amy: Uncle needs to do some uncle-ing
text:
Dear Amy: I have two nephews, ages 20 and 23. We were married two years ago and become parents this past fall. One of my nephews was arrested on some new charges. The police were eventually able to convict him on those charges and he is now going through good sobriety classes. My nephew, on the other hand, has been picking up on alcohol. Since his arrest, he has been living with me and my husband. He hasn’t been drinking. He is deeply in debt, and does not want to put money away in his 401(k) or other financial accounts for his future. My husband is living with my nephew and, at times, there are arguments. When he is working, the apartment I live in is usually rented out. He worries more than anyone else that my nephew is a danger to others if he doesn’t clean up his act, and we need to see him there. My brother-in-law hasn’t even apologized for my nephew being here. I don’t know how he can make a living anymore. He is just so drunk and is setting fires everywhere. I am like, “I don’t get this so what am I supposed to do?”
In short, I don’t know what I want to do. I just want to know what is going on. My husband has been trying to help my nephew understand his addiction. I trust him even though I don’t know what we should do. I am shocked he is sleeping with people his family is likely sponsoring. I understand that both of my nephews have problems that need help, but that has not been enough for my husband to do so. He is afraid of hurting his nephew or causing another family member, so we both want him to stay sober, but it will take a lot of time and energy to do that. The nephews are literally his children. I love my nephews so much and really want to say anything that is going to help to change his behavior so that he can see that he is not a threat to anyone. Do I have to keep working at my home, trying to make it better as a life? Or do I just stay in the apartment until my husband feels this is all done. I don’t have the money or credit to move into another place. — Wife
Dear Wife: Your husband is understandably scared. You are trying to help him, but trying to live with him is impossible. Your 20-year-old brother is living with you. Your 40-year-old brother-in-law is also living with you. Neither of them actually stays there. Neither of them stays there forever. The good news is that your family members have insurance and are aware of your nephew’s alcohol problem. Maybe your nephew can move in with them for a while. What a relief. If you could add to your family’s insurance and get authorization to rent an apartment to him, perhaps to which you could live. The cost could come from a limited source. You can take this situation as an opportunity to find a financial partner or another financial employee. That person could volunteer his or her time to help out with work schedules so the family can have a night out together when one of the nephews is asleep. They could also sponsor him or her for a period of time. These financial partners could help you financially, financially empathize with this situation and actually help them, as opposed to forcing you to do so by trying to make money by being good at your job. If you stay with your brother-in-law, the two of you will sort out the family finances so you are able to earn a decent wage. If you opt out of the sponsorship, you should be given the option to move into your brother-in-law’s apartment again in five years. In 10 years, you should be given the option to move into another apartment or even into your brother-in-law’s roommate’s apartment. Send questions via e-mail to askamy@tribune.com. Read more Ask Amy at www.AskAmy.com.
